question: All of the following are seen in anemia of chronic disease except:
options:
a)High serum hepcidin
b)Low serum ferritin
c)chronic infection
d)Adequate iron stores
solution:
Low serum ferritin levels are not seen in anemia of chronic disease.
Anemia of chronic disease is anemia resulting due to chronic diseases which produce systemic inflammation. During chronic inflammation, inflammatory mediators like interleukin - 6(IL-6) stimulate the production of hepcidin from the liver. Hepcidin is an acute phase reactant that



inhibits ferroportin on macrophages and also decreases iron from stores to developing RBc
precursors. This results in decreased proliferation of erythroid progenitors due to impaired iron utilization.
By decreasing available serum iron, the body defends itself from certain bacteria(Eg, Hemophilus influenza) that require iron for their pathogenicity. The lab findings seen in anemia of chronic
disease are:
• Low serum iron
• Decreased total iron-binding capacity
• Abundant stored iron
• Increased hepcidin levels
• Increased serum ferritin
The chronic illnesses associated with  anemia of chronic disease can be grouped into three categories:
• chronic microbial infections, such as osteomyelitis, bacterial endocarditis, and lung abscess
• chronic immune disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis and regional enteritis
• Neoplasms, such as carcinomas ofthe lung and breast and Hodgkin lymphoma
Note: Hepcidin is the main regulator of iron absorption which is encoded by the HAMP gene and is defective in hemochromatosis.

question: Identify the true statement/s regarding clear cell carcinoma of the kidney
solution:
True statements regarding clear cell carcinoma of the kidney are 1, 4. Clear cell carcinoma is
the most common sporadic renal cell cancer and cells show intracellular accumulation of glycogen



and fat.
clear cell cancer arises from the proximal tubular epithelium and usually occurs as solitary unilateral lesions.
Most of the cases are sporadic, but can also occur either in familial forms or in association
with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease. They are associated with the loss of sequence of the short arm of chromosome 3. Those with VHL disease inherit a germline mutation of the VHL gene on   chromosomal band 3p25 and lose the second allele by somatic mutation.
The VHL protein causes the degradation of hypoxia-induced factors (HIFs), which are
transcription factors that contribute to carcinogenesis by stimulating the expression of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) that helps drive tumour cell growth.
Histologically, the tumour cells have a rounded or polygonal shape and abundant clear or granular cytoplasm, which contains glycogen and lipids.
Given below is the histopathological image of clear cell carcinoma.


cancerous cells produce various abnormal hormones resulting in paraneoplastic syndrome. These include polycythemia, hypercalcemia, cushing syndrome, amyloidosis and hypertension.
The most common site of metastasis is the lungs and bones. Radical nephrectomy is the treatment of choice. But T1a(size less than 4cm) tumours are treated by nephron-sparing surgery or partial    nephrectomy to preserve renal function. Drugs that inhibit VEGF and tyrosine kinase inhibitors
are used as an adjunct therapy for metastatic disease.

Genomic imprinting refers to gene silencing/ inactivation. Here either the maternal or the
paternal allele is inactivated resulting in only one functional allele. It occurs by the process of



epigenetics, where gene expression is lowered by:
• DNA methylation
• Histone deacetylation
Genomic imprinting is best illustrated by two uncommon genetic disorders: prader-willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome.

question: which of the following is a marker of natural killer cell?
options:
a)CD 68
b)CD 3
c)CD 25
d)CD 94
solution:
The marker of the natural killer cells is CD94. It is expressed in natural killer cells and a small subset of T lymphocytes.
Natural killer cells (NK cells) are essential cells of innate immunity. They act against malignant and virus-infected cells. NK cells are identified by CD16 and CD56 cell surface receptors.
NK cells' activity is augmented by interferons and upon activation, they bind to glycoprotein receptors on the surface of target cells and release perforins. perforins create pores in the
membrane of the target cells. Through these pores, cytotoxic factors like tumor necrosis factor-beta (TNF-β) enter the cells and destroy them by apoptosis.
NK cells express a phenomenon known as antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC). Here, NK cells have the capability of killing target cells that are coated by IgG antibodies.

option A: CD68 is expressed on macrophages and monocytes.
option B: CD 3 is a T-cell receptor marker. They are involved in the transduction of signals to the T cells when an antigen binds to the T cell receptor.

Laryngeal papillomatosis or juvenile papillomatosis is the most common benign neoplasm of
the larynx in children. It is caused by HPV 6 and 11. It involves supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx. Adult-onset laryngeal papillomatosis involves the anterior part of the vocal cords.
It usually occurs between the ages 3–5 years, but less commonly can also occur in men aged between 3o-5o years. Clinical features include hoarseness or aphonia and respiratory
difficulty. The recurrence rate is high but they rarely transform to SCC.
Diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy. Treatment consists of micro
laryngoscopy, Co2 laser excision, and topical cidofovir.

question:
A boy presents with recurrent episodes of melena. on examination, there was eczema of the skin with multiple petechiae. His platelet count was low but RBC and wBC counts were
within normal limits. which of the following is the diagnostic investigation in this patient?
options:
a)wASP gene mutation
b)Anti platelet antibodies
c)Bone marrow biopsy
d)Electron microscopy
solution:
The given scenario of recurrent episodes of melena, eczema, and multiple petechiae along with
low platelet counts is suggestive of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. The diagnostic investigation in this patient is WASP gene mutation testing.
Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome(WAS) is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder. It is caused by mutations in the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASp) that primarily affects the T
lymphocytes.
Normally, WASp regulates the actin cytoskeleton and thus helps in cell adhesion, migration, and the formation of synapses between antigen-presenting and target cells. In WAS, there is a
progressive loss of T lymphocytes in the peripheral blood resulting in defects in cellular
immunity.
The clinical features of WAS are recurrent bacterial infections, eczema, and bleeding due
to thrombocytopenia. Patients with WAS are prone to develop B-cell lymphomas and autoimmune disorders.
The image given below shows eczema seen in WAS





Diagnosis is based on intracellular immunofluorescence analysis of wAS protein (wASp)
expression in blood cells. IgM levels in the serum are low, but levels of IgG are usually normal. Reduced-sized platelet is a typical feature of wAS.
The only curative treatment is an allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant. prophylactic
antibiotics, immunoglobulin G (IgG) supplementation, and topical treatment for eczema can be tried. Gene therapy trials are also under research.

question: which of the following is not a part of innate immunity?
options:
a)Alpha defensins
b)B lymphocytes
c)Gamma Delta T lymphocytes
d)Lectin pathway
solution:
B lymphocytes are not a part of innate immunity. B lymphocytes are part of adaptive immunity.
Innate immunity is an intrinsic mechanism that provides the first line of defence against
infections. It is non-specific, provides immediate defence against microbes, and helps eliminate damaged cells.
components of Innate Immunity are:
• Epithelial cells - these produce antimicrobial molecules such as alpha-defensins
• Macrophages and neutrophils
• Dendritic cells - these have receptors that sense microbes and cell damage. They stimulate secretion of cytokines, which play important role in inflammation and antiviral defence
• Innate lymphoid cells (ILcs) - these are local tissue lymphocytes that lack T-cell antigen receptors. They produce inflammatory cytokines during the early phases of immune
reactions. Gamma delta T lymphocytes and natural killer (NK) cells belong to this class
• Mast cells
• complement pathway - it include complement proteins of alternative and lectin pathways.

question: which of the following disorders is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern?
options:
a)Rett syndrome
b)Duchenne muscular dystrophy
c)Huntington disease
d)Tuberous sclerosis
solution:
Rett syndrome is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.
Rett syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder. It is caused due to mutation in the MECP-2 gene. The disorder is mostly seen in girls because affected boys usually die in infancy due to a defective single X chromosome.
Symptoms of Rett syndrome are microcephaly, developmental delay, autistic-like behavior, cognitive dysfunction, seizures, and repetitive motor actions.
other options:
option B: Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is inherited in X linked recessive pattern. It occurs due to a mutation in the dystrophin gene. Typical features include calf muscle
pseudohypertrophy and Gower's sign (using arms to lift themselves from a seated position).
Laboratory investigations show elevated serum creatine kinase levels. Casimersen has been recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of DMD.
option C: Huntington's disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It is a trinucleotide (CAG) repeat disorder and shows genetic anticipation (earlier onset of disease or increased
severity in succeeding generations). Patients present with involuntary movements known as chorea. Tetrabenazine is used for treatment.
option D: Tuberous sclerosis also known as Bournville disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It occurs due to mutation in TSC1 and TSC2 genes. It is characterized by subependymal nodules, angiomyolipomas, cafe au lait spots, shagreen patches, and cardiac rhabdomyomas.

question: cell in cell appearance is seen in:
options:

b)Apoptosis
c)Necroptosis
d)Entosis
solution:
Cell in cell appearance is seen in entosis.
Entosis is a phenomenon where a cell engulfs a cell of the same type. while cells that are internalised by this mechanism are initially viable. But, the majority of them undergo a
non-apoptotic form of cell death. It plays a physiological role in the elimination of cells detached from a surface.
other options:
option A: Necrosis is a pathologic process of irreversible cell death following severe injury. It is
associated with local inflammation due to damaged cell membranes. Some microscopic features of necrosis are as follows:
• Dilation of mitochondria
• Nuclear changes: karyolysis, pyknosis, and karyorrhexis.
• Myelin figures replacing dead cells.
option B: Apoptosis is a pathway of programmed cell death. In apoptosis, Mitochondrial and    death receptor pathways activate caspases resulting in the formation of apoptotic bodies which are then phagocytosed.



option C: Necroptosis is a type of cell death which is a hybrid of both necrosis and apoptosis. It is also called programmed necrosis/caspase-independent programmed cell death(since it does not      result in caspase activation).

question: How does phagolysosome cause cell death?
options:
a)Is both intra and extra cellular
b)can fuse with other organelles directly
c)Fuses with lysosome to form autophagolysosome
d)Is a single membrane structure
solution:
phagolysosomes cause cell death by the fusion of lysosomes to form autophagolysosomes.
Autophagy is a process in which a cell eats its own contents. Cytoplasmic materials are delivered  and degraded by the lysosome. It is a survival technique of the cell in nutrient deprivation states.
The steps are:
• An isolation membrane called phagophore is formed and nucleated.
• phagophore is derived from the ER with the help of plasma membrane and mitochondria
• A double membrane-bound vesicle is formed from the isolation membrane called the autophagosome
• Maturation of the autophagosome by fusion with lysosomes, called autophagolysosome.
Apoptosis is a regulated mechanism of eliminating unwanted and damaged cells. It is initiated by enzymes called caspases and is executed by two different pathways. The mitochondrial
pathway which is also known as the intrinsic pathway carries out the majority of the apoptosis. The death receptor pathway or the extrinsic pathway is initiated by plasma membrane death
receptors. Both these pathways combine together and activate the caspase cascade which results



in the final phase of apoptosis.
pyroptosis is a form of apoptosis mediated by fever-inducing cytokine IL-1. A multiprotein
complex called inflammasome is activated when microorganisms enter the cell. It will in turn activate caspase 1 which cleaves the IL-1 precursor and releases its biologically active form.

question: B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time due to which phenomenon?
options:
a)Somatic hypermutation
b)Alternative RNA splicing
c)Affinity maturation
d)Allelic exclusion
solution:
B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time due to alternative RNA splicing.
Alternative RNA splicing is the process by which different proteins are produced from the same RNA transcript by splicing it in different ways.
Mature circulating B cells initially express IgM and IgD antibodies on their surfaces before they
are stimulated to produce specific antibodies. The heavy chains in IgM and IgD are mu (μ)
and delta (δ), respectively. The mu and delta genes for these heavy chains are located proximal to  the VDJ encoding regions (i.e., variable, diversity, and joining regions) of the heavy chain locus. A primary RNA transcript of this entire region is produced, which then undergoes alternative RNA   processing, enabling the production of both transmembrane IgM and IgD on B cells.
other options:
options A and C: somatic hypermutation is a cellular response by which the immune system
adapts to the new foreign elements that confront it. They do so by adding nucleotides in V gene



regions of heavy and light chains, resulting in a better fit of antigen with the antibodies. This
hence increases the affinity of antibodies to antigens. Due to this, the subset of plasma cells with these improved hypervariable regions are more strongly selected by the antigen and therefore
constitute a larger part of the population of antibody-producing cells. This process is called affinity maturation.
option D: Allelic exclusion is the process by which a cell expresses one of the two alleles of the gene and excludes the other allele.
B cells are diploid, therefore, each B cell has six gene segment pools related to antibody chains:
• Two heavy-chain pools (one from each parent) and
• Four light-chain pools (one κ and one λ from each parent).
However, each B cell uses only two of the six gene segment pools: one out of the two heavy-chain pools (maternal and paternal) and one out of the four light-chain pools. Thus, each B cell must     choose not only between its κ and λ light-chain pools but also between its maternal and paternal  light-chain and heavy-chain pools. This process of choosing is by allelic exclusion.

question:
A 1o-year-old boy presented with fatigue. Investigations revealed: Hemoglobin, 9 g/dL; MCV, 6o fL; MCH, 2o pg; and serum ferritin, 185 μg/L. The TLC was elevated and showed

options:

b)Anemia of chronic disorder
c)Iron-deficiency anemia
d)sickle cell anemia
solution:
The given clinical scenario and the investigation findings are suggestive of microcytic
hypochromic anemia. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is anemia of chronic disorder.
Anemia of chronic disorders more commonly presents as normochromic normocytic anemia that later develops into microcytic hypochromic anemia rarely. It is caused due to production of
erythrocytes.
Anemia of chronic disease is anemia resulting due to chronic diseases which produce systemic inflammation. During chronic inflammation, inflammatory mediators like interleukin - 6
(IL-6) stimulate the production of hepcidin from the liver. Hepcidin is an acute phase
reactant that inhibits ferroportin on macrophages and also decreases transport of iron from stores to developing RBC precursors. This results in decreased proliferation of erythroid progenitors due to impaired iron utilization.

and hence does not have iron deficiency anemia.
Note:
MCV/RBC count (Mentzer index) can also be used to distinguish thalassemia from iron-deficiency anemia (IDA). MCV (mean corpuscular volume) and MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin) are
low in both IDA and thalassemia. RBC count may be normal in thalassemia, whereas it is reduced in IDA. A lower RBC count in IDA means the denominator is smaller, yielding a greater MCV/RBC ratio.

question: senile atrophy occurs due to ______.
options:
a)Denervation
b)Decreased nutrition
c)Decreased workload
d)Reduced blood supply
solution:
senile atrophy is seen when there is a reduced blood supply to a tissue. This reduction in the    blood supply occurs in a gradual manner because of slowly progressing atherosclerotic lesions.
Atrophy is a process of reduction in the size of a tissue or an organ resulting from a decrease in   the cell size and number. It is a type of cellular adaptation. In this process, there is a decrease in the synthesis of cellular proteins and an increase in their degradation, mainly mediated by the     ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. Atrophy can either be physiological or pathological:
physiologic atrophy:
• Loss of hormonal stimulation: Atrophy of the uterus after parturition; atrophy of the endometrium, vaginal epithelium, and breast after menopause.
• During embryonic development: Certain structures, like the notochord and thyroglossal duct, undergo atrophy during fetal development.
pathologic atrophy:
• Disuse Atrophy (decreased workload): e.g., atrophy in a limb that has been immobilized following a fracture
• Denervation atrophy (loss of nerve supply): e.g., skeletal muscle atrophy following nerve injury
• Ischemic atrophy: e.g., senile atrophy of the brain and heart due to atherosclerosis
• Inadequate nutrition: e.g., severe muscle wasting in marasmus
• pressure atrophy: e.g., atrophy of surrounding uninvolved tissues caused by an enlarging benign tumor

question: A 7-year-old child presents with fever, erythematous rash, and bone pain. X-ray of the skull shows multiple lytic lesions. solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the histopathological image showing Langerhans cells with folded nuclei (image A), CD1a (image B), and positive S1oo (image C), is suggestive of
Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).
LCH occurs due to the proliferation of a special type of immature dendritic cells,
called Langerhans cells. Their normal function is to present antigens. The most common mutation is the BRAFv6ooE gain-of-function mutation.
It is characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions and can also infiltrate nearly every organ, like the skin (of the scalp), lungs, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous

results in otitis media and mastoiditis. spinal involvement results in compression fractures and
neurological involvement. vertebral involvement results in a rapid flattening of the vertebral body (vertebra plana).
Histopathologically, Langerhans cells have a single large nucleus with a characteristic folded or
grooved nucleus (coffee-bean appearance) with small inconspicuous nucleoli. Birbeck granules are

question: Hereditary angioedema is due to a defect in which of the proteins mentioned below?
options:
a)C1 inhibitor
b)Decay accelerating factor
c)CD59
d)C5 convertase
solution:
Hereditary angioedema is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by a deficiency of C1     esterase inhibitors. C1 esterase inhibitors usually target proteases like C1r and C1s, factor XII and the kallikrein system. Therefore, their deficiency leads to unregulated activation of kallikrein,
leading to increased bradykinin.
Clinical features include swelling of the skin and mucosal surfaces, nausea, vomiting, and
diarrhea, which may be aggravated after minor trauma or emotional stress. The condition can be treated by giving C1 inhibitor concentrates from human plasma.
The main inflammatory mediator responsible for these symptoms is bradykinin. Bradykinin is an inflammatory mediator formed by the cleavage of kininogen, in the presence of the enzyme
kallikrein. Bradykinin has the following effects:
• Increases the vascular permeability
• Causes contraction of smooth muscle
• Dilates the blood vessel
• Mediates pain
other options:
options B and C: Decay-accelerating factor (DAF) and CD59 are two proteins that are linked by a glycophosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor to the plasma membrane. DAF prevents the formation of C3 convertases and CD59 inhibits the formation of the MAC. An acquired deficiency of the
enzyme that creates GPI anchors leads to a deficiency of these regulators and excessive
complement activation and lysis of red cells resulting in Paroxysmal nocturnal
hemoglobinuria(PNH).
During inflammation, C5a (option D), C3a, and C4a, which are all cleavage products of their
corresponding complement components, stimulate mast cells to release histamine. They have
effects similar to those of mast cell mediators involved in anaphylactic reactions and therefore, are



called anaphylatoxins. C5a is also chemotactic for neutrophils, monocytes, eosinophils, and
basophils. Additionally, it activates the lipooxygenase pathway of arachidonic acid metabolism in neutrophils and monocytes, resulting in the further release of inflammatory mediators.

question: A 35-year-old woman presents with fatigue. Investigations revealed the following: Hb, 5 gm    %; MCH, 24; low MCV; leukocytes, 11,ooo/uL, and platelets, 5 lakhs. The peripheral smear is shown below. what is the diagnosis?

c)Thalassemia major

solution:
The given scenario of a 35 year old woman, her iron profile and peripheral smear showing microcytic hypochromic anemia are suggestive of iron-deficiency anemia (IDA).
IDA is an example of microcytic hypochromic anemia. The causes of IDA can be inadequate diet, impaired reabsorption, increased requirement and increased blood loss.
The manifestations of IDA depend upon the underlying cause. In general, IDA presents with    koilonychia, alopecia, atrophic changes in the tongue, gastric mucosa, malabsorbtion and pica (craving for consumption of non-edible materials)
peripheral smears show small and pale red cells typically described as microcytic (reduced MCV) and hypochromic (enlarged zone of central pallor). poikilocytosis can be seen in the form of
elongated red cells, known as pencil cells. Target cells can be found in cases of severe IDA.
Diagnosis is mainly by laboratory studies. The typical findings are:
• Low hemoglobin and hematocrit
• Low serum iron and ferretin
• Increased Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)
• Hepcidin is low (decreased stores of iron inhibit hepcidin synthesis)
IDA is treated by giving oral and parenteral preparations if iron or packed cell transfusion depending upon the severity of the anemia.

Adenocarcinomas grow in various patterns: acinar, lepidic, papillary, micropapillary, and solid.
The lesions are small and are usually located in the periphery.  At the periphery of the tumor there is often a lepidic pattern of spread, in which the tumor cells “crawl” along normal-appearing

b)IL-6

solution:
INF-γ is not involved in Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (JHR).
JHR is a condition that occurs in patients infected by spirochetes who undergo antibiotic
treatment. The reaction occurs within 24 hours of antibiotic treatment. clinical features are fever, chills, nausea and vomiting, tachycardia, hypotension, flushing, myalgia, and exacerbation of skin lesions.

disease, louse-borne relapsing fever, leptospirosis, and tick-borne relapsing fever. Antibiotics that have been most associated are penicillins, tetracyclines, and erythromycin.
Mild reactions are self-limiting and often resolve spontaneously within 24 hours. Prevention of the JHR is by giving TNF-alpha antibodies and in some cases steroids.
